data_findings.finding: This is a 2D bin packing optimization problem: pack Christmas tree shapes (15-vertex polygons) into the smallest square bounding box for N=1 to 200 trees. Score = sum of (side^2 / N) for all N.

Key techniques from top kernels: 1) Greedy placement with weighted angles (sin(2*angle) distribution), 2) Simulated Annealing (SA) with local moves, 3) Squeeze/compaction toward center, 4) Rotation optimization using ConvexHull + minimize_scalar, 5) Overlap detection using Shapely polygons with STRtree spatial indexing

Advanced optimization techniques: 1) bbox3 binary optimizer with multi-phase approach (short/medium/long runs), 2) fix_direction rotation tightening, 3) Overlap repair by replacing invalid groups with known-good solutions, 4) Backward propagation - removing boundary-touching trees from larger N to improve smaller N configurations

C++ optimizers are critical for performance: tree_packer with OpenMP parallelization, swap moves, multi-start SA with higher temperature, boundary tree identification, and backward propagation from N=200 down to N=2

Global dynamics optimization: Complex number vector coordination, fluid dynamics simulation, hinge pivot moves, density gradient flow, global boundary tension, and aggressive overlap repair cycles using separation vectors (MTV approximation)

Key algorithms for 2D irregular polygon packing: 1) Genetic algorithms with local search hybridization, 2) Simulated annealing, 3) Tabu search, 4) Shelf packing algorithms with object transformations, 5) No-Fit Polygon (NFP) for collision detection, 6) Jostle algorithm for local search

web_research.query: What are the best algorithms for 2D irregular polygon packing optimization problems?
web_research.finding: The best algorithms for 2D irregular polygon packing optimization problems encompass a variety of approaches, including heuristic, metaheuristic, and exact methods. Metaheuristic algorithms such as genetic algorithms, simulated annealing, and tabu search have been widely applied due to their ability to navigate large and complex search spaces effectively. For instance, a review from 2001 highlights the use of genetic algorithms specifically tailored for irregular packing problems, emphasizing their flexibility and effectiveness in handling the combinatorial nature of these tasks ([Springer](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1023/A:1012590107280)). More recent research has focused on hybrid approaches, combining genetic algorithms with local search heuristics to improve solution quality and computational efficiency, especially in applications involving multiple bin sizes and irregular shapes ([MDPI](https://www.mdpi.com/2076-3417/13/22/12474), [University of Southampton](https://epri
